newsitem.title: USA: U of Illinois files patent on corn-butanol process.
newsitem.headline: U of Illinois files patent on corn-butanol process.

text.p: The University of Illinois and the Illinois Corn Marketing Board (ICMB) have jointly filed for a patent on a new production process to make butanol from corn rather than petroleum, the IMCB said on Friday.
Butanol is a chemical used in plastics production, as a food grade extractant in the food and flavor industry, and as a solvent for paints and brake fluids.
"If the 10 billion pounds of butanol currently on the market were made from corn, this would result in a new market for 136 million bushels of corn," said ICMB chairman Gene Youngquist.
The new process uses fermentation methods and a mutant strain of bacteria called C. Beijernickii to convert corn to butanol at twice the previous capacity, the IMCB said.

IMCB said the end-product is also more concentrated than petroleum-based butanol and energy costs to remove water from butanol would be 60 percent less with the corn-based product than with the petroleum-based process.
Illinois ranks second in U.S. corn production after Iowa.

IMCB administers farmer "checkoff" contributions of 1/4 cent per bushel to invest in research and promotion. IMCB has patent royalty agreements with the University of Illinois and Southern Illinois University.
